It looks like the crimson parser is giving you some grief.  It looks like it 
is trying to read an xml file over a network.  Could you try the following:
- use and ibm vm instead of Sun's vm (Sun uses crimson and IBM uses Xerces)
- or make sure the xml file is local and there is no need for crimson to try 
for a network connection (this is what is causing the 2-3 min 'hang')

Response from Pritpal Dhaliwal:

Thanks a lot for reponding to the bug. My xml file is on a network share. Is
there a way for me to change my default xml parser in sun jvm?

I don't mind using the IBM jvm, Its just that my app is compiled using Sun
JVM and not sure if it is appropriate for me to switch jvms.

I don't know of any way to change the parser in Sun's vm (it is likely you 
can't).  I only suggested you use IBM's vm to determine that this was an issue 
with crimson (as opposed to Eclipse).  From what you have said, this is an 
issue with crimson.  Will close this PR.

my build.xml parses fine which is sitting on the same network share..

I am already connected to the network share before I try to right click on the 
file. When I double click, I can get it to open in the perspective ( editor ).

Paul
*** Bug 51152 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I think we need to put some pressure back on the core guys to keep shipping
Xerces with eclipse.  Problems like this are too serious to ignore.

This does not appear to be a Crimson only issue.  I tried to parse an XML file 
with an external DTD with Xerces and it too attempted to download the DTD while 
parsing.

Turning off validation did not seem to help at all.  The only thing that worked 
(for xerces) was to turn off external DTD loading using 
the "http://apache.org/xml/features/nonvalidating/load-external-dtd" feature.  
I could not find anything similar for Crimson, and from what i saw from the 
Crimson code it isn't actually possible using features...

I did find an atricle on how to stop DTD loading and it suggested to use an 
entity resolver that does nothig.  This seems to be the most portable 
solution.  Here is a snippet that demonstrates the resolver:

public class NoOpEntityResolver implements EntityResolver {
  public InputSource resolveEntity(String publicId, String systemId) {
    return new InputSource(new StringBufferInputStream(""));
  }
}


Could this bug please be re-opened, to recognise that there is a problem with 
loading these types of XML files?

Here is the xml file i used for my testing (slow enough on a 33.6 modem):

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE web-app PUBLIC
   "-//Sun Microsystems, Inc.//DTD Web Application 2.3//EN"
   "http://java.sun.com/dtd/web-app_2_3.dtd">
<web-app>
</web-app>
Reopening as per Brock's comment above.

Created an attachment (id=7927)
Patch to stop external resolving

This patch will resolve all external entities to an empty string.  The patch
was created against 3.0 M7.
*** Bug 55617 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Debbie, can you check out that patch and commit it if it's good?  We need this
for M8.
Patch has been applied.  Fix available post-200403231208.
If you were experiencing this problem, can you verify if it is fixed?
Changing to VERIFIED.  Thanks for the extra testing.
